content.html:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

  1. Here is a graph that represents \(y=x^2\). 

Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. On the same coordinate plane, sketch a graph that represents \(y=(x−6)^2+10\). 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

A graph the same shape as \(y=x^2\) but shifted 6 units to the right and 10 units upward. Its vertex is at \((6,10)\).

  1. The graph representing \(y=x^2\) is shifted 2 units to the left, 10 units down, and flipped so that it opens downward, as shown. 

Which equation defines this curve?

  • \(y=-(x+2)^2−10\)
  • \(y=(x+2)^2−10\)
  • \(y=-(x+2)^2+10\)
  • \(y=(x+2)^2+10\)

Answer: \(y=-(x+2)^2−10\)

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will revisit vertex form at the end of Unit 9. This cool down goes beyond the understanding of vertex form students need to demonstrate on the Unit 7 Quiz.
